Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: threat and non-threat. Threat is a statement that indicates someone will be hurt or harmed, especially if the person does not do something in particular.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Enough already.  Cut the head off this snake.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment conveys a death threat to someone.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Disgusting comment, I pity anyone who has to live with you.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment might be toxic but is not a threat.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Bravo!  Bravo!

Encore!! Encore!! Encore!!
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is clearly unrelated to threat and should be non-threat.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: ... after shooting her with her own gun.

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: If you think putting Alaska Natives in charge of ANY natural resource will provide any degree of protection or conservation, you apparently do not read much. Check out the history of the Kilbuck caribou herd. Or, if you really want an education, go to Bethel in May and June when the Kuskokwim delta is filled with ducks and geese tending their nests. You can watch fifteen or twenty boats go out there every morning and spend the day killing ducks and geese even though it is totally illegal and unethical, until their boats are literally full, then coming back to town, taking a dozen or two home for supper, coming back the next day, dumping the other hundred or so dead birds out of the boat and going back out to blast a couple hundred more. Yep, they are definitely "Stewards of the Land" alright. Or go do a census of game within 30 miles of ANY village in NW or SW Alaska. No moose, no caribou. If it moves, kill it. If it flies it dies.

Comment: Whoever introduced that vile bird vetch into Alaska should be hung, drawn and quartered!  Talk about invasive!  I don't think I have seen any more ecologically damaging plant in Alaska to match it, including dandelions.  At least most invasive plant species in Alaska seem to stick to disturbed soil such as roadsides and lawns, but not this nasty plant --- I have been seeing vast swathes of it in relatively open woodlands as well, particularly in and around the area near the Palmer Agricultural Experimental Station on Trunk Road where it was presumably first introduced.  I've seen it climbing up and pulling down wild rose and mooseberry plants, and I shudder to think what our woods and roadsides are going to look like in another ten or twenty years if this bird vetch cannot be controlled (which it almost certainly cannot be at this point).

Comment: Taking care of sick people will never be profitable, this is the fundamental reason free market health care will never work. Comparing LASIK, a voluntary procedure, to rounds of chemotherapy or treatment for MS is absurd. The idea that "choice" is key makes sense only for healthy people seeking elective procedures. What choice is there is your kid has cancer? Millions of dollars in care or they die. What if they need a kidney transplant? The problem is that people can move from "healthy" to "in dire need of care" in a literal heartbeat. I've watched healthy active friends be diagnosed with cancer and ALS in their 20's, without insurance they would simply die. Full stop. No one can save enough or clip enough coupons to pay for that treatment. Pretending that people get sick because they have no financial motivation to stay healthy, or that the issue is voluntary treatment, is absolute nonsense. Not to mention the absurd costs you incur when older, that are paid forward by insurance.

Comment: LOTL, that petition you mention in your last sentence can be read in John's Gospel  (17:21). Since you made the sentence an exclamation, I presume that you, like me, recognize just how pivotal is the petition to (and how definitional of) any genuine claim to be Jesus' disciple. What exactly was Jesus asking of his Father? If you read to the end of the chapter, the answer is clearly stated: "...that the love with which thou hast loved me may be in them, and I in them." The unity Jesus seeks of his followers is primarily a unity in love, not doctrine. I don't deny the importance of doctrine, but I do deny that it has supreme importance. Belief in (intellectual assent to) the dogma of the Eucharist cannot redeem a person: only Eucharistic love, manifested in and through word and deed, can do this. Note, however, that intellectual assent to Eucharistic dogma is not a condition for exercising the love referenced by the dogma.

Comment: A foolish comment.  I'm in this line of work.  Many wells are placed close to overhead powerlines, it is the responsibility of the person servicing the well to be sure they are positioned in such a way as to avoid the lines.  In order to pull a failed pump from a well a boom must go up.  The operator of this truck failed to notice the lines and unfortunately set into them.  A pump serviceman  sets his truck up several times a day at different locations, overhead lines are common and we are always looking out for them.  Occasionally someone misses the fact that there are lines present and set directly into them.   To suggest that this company was trying to not follow rules shows just how little you know about what you are commenting on.  This was clearly an accident.  That man had more than likely set that truck up thousands of times safely and was almost certainly safe and professional  in his conduct.  We are all prone to make mistakes, it's to bad his cost him his life.

Comment: Cracked column basalt and a transition forest that goes from oak savannah to rain forest conifer to rain shadow pine to oak savannah to high desert.   The slides will be released by water freezing and expanding,  and then thawing,  and rain lubricating the now loosened rocks.   Freezing is one of the important factors.  And rain on frozen ground can be a flash flood event.

Dead,  burned trees,  rot at the mean annual winter  snow level,  be that one foot   or four or more.  You can actually accurately guess the mean annual winter snow level by the height of the stumps from  blowdown in a burn area.  The real danger over time will be snag toboggans rocketing towards the railroad and freeway.....or the back of your home.  

Salvage log or not (that area is mostly helicopter logging ground),  the dead trees will fall.  The issue is who gets to control the aftermath.  My life experience includes fire watch duties,  and when the afternoon humidity dropped,  trees fell.  Wet rot dried out.

Comment: Christian realism is a foreign policy perspective that originated with Reinhold Niebuhr, the famous moral theologian and public intellectual who was really a titanic figure on the American scene from the 1930s into the 1960s. The essence of Christian realism—which is very much at odds with anything that smacks of utopianism—is to appreciate that there is evil in the world to which we must respond but also to appreciate that our own motives are likely to be less pure than we may fancy them to be. It’s not simply that the motives of the other guys are suspect but we ourselves should always be mindful of the extent to which our own motives [may] be subject to question.
Andrew Bacevich

Comment: Kaniela Ing, Hawaii legislature committee chairman, unethically disappeared written testimony by Ken Conklin on two different bills on the same day this year.

Kaniela Ing's bill would enact into law a racial restriction on who can run for OHA trustee.  In year 2000 the U.S. Supreme Court ruled (Rice v. Cayetano) that it is unconstitutional to have a racial restriction on who can VOTE for OHA trustees.  Later 2 federal courts ruled (Arakaki vs. State of Hawaii) that it is unconstitutional to have a racial restriction on who can RUN as a candidate for OHA. Conklin's testimony in opposition to this bill pointed out that chairman Ing is too young to remember the court decisions from 2000, but that's no excuse for a committee chairman who should have access to legal advice before introducing a truly stupid bill. Comment: Listen ... But ... can non-Indigenous people write about Indigenous issues? The answer is ... must always be ... a resounding yes. 

That's because all writing, like any artform, is inherently organic. As humans, we write to inform, inspire or provoke. We do this by writing about what inform, inspires and provokes us.   Writing should never be bounded by race or ideology or cultural "experiences."

This hubbub is going to have a chilling effect on the writing and coverage of indigenous subjects in Canada.

Comment: Your post saddens me. Not because I disagree, but because there is much truth in it.

My family came to Eugene two decades ago. We fell in love with the neighborhood grocery stores (Kiva, Red Barn, New Frontier, Sundance, Brun's Apple (formerly Red Apple)) and the incredible potential we saw here. That potential remains, but the direction over the past decade has been disturbing, at best. 

We're car-free, so we chose a location to live that put us close to all the amenities we want regularly without having to deal with horridly lousy streets. That puts us near the river. Twenty years ago, there were homeless people along the river, but they were few in both number and impact. In fact, they were kind of quaint and we helped several out, including providing housing. Now, the riverfront is disgusting, filled with garbage, feces, used needles and aggressive bums. Good night, what a difference.

I wish Mayor Vinis all the best, but I am now seriously considering relocating and it pains me.

Your reply to AKDorf is thoughtful, even as I must say I am asking some of the same questions as him/her.

For me, it's not the idea of "blam[ing] all [blacks]" for the poor conduct of some, as you suggest. Instead, it is wondering when the high-profile athletes -- who would likely wield meaningful sway in the black communities -- are going to challenge the people to start taking those very steps mentioned above, to accept some of the responsibility for initiating the changes they want to see. Such a shift in attitudes within the community would begin narrowing, even if slowly, the consequence-free arena in which the miscreants act with impunity, in what is ultimately more damaging to the law-abiding than to themselves.

The problems the black community faces cannot *all* be the doing of whites. To suggest so is ludicrous, and to me the repeated, sweeping claim of "racism" -- in a nation which just had a two-term black President -- seems to sidestep the issue of accountability.

Comment: Linking transportation choices and emissions to density and building size is just plain stupid. While it is true that a handful of dense European cities happen to have much lower rates of driving than our less-dense cities, there both a variety of reasons for that and a host of similarly compact dense cities in Europe with similar rates of car addiction as we have to show that there is no correlation.

Why are people riding bikes in Copenhagen and not here? How about the fact that Copenhagen has extensive, automated traffic law enforcement and licenses are difficult and expensive to obtain but easy to lose. Here, we give out licenses like Cracker Jack prizes and do no meaningful traffic law enforcement. They also have extensive high quality public transit that works well for multi-modal trips. That's part of the reason their median trip by bike is less than half a mile. 

Now, why aren't the people of Dublin, Rome and Paris on their bikes? They have density, but not the other features.

When someone is stating that the potency of cannabis is making it dangerous, and compares it with a known deadly toxin like 100% ethanol, me pointing out that there has never, in the history of the world, been a case of fatal cannabis overdose, regardless of the potency, is a valid counter argument. 

However, there is no reason to believe that legalized cannabis and sensible policy like we are seeing in Colorado automatically makes anyone in favor of allowing pilots or truck drivers or neurosurgeons to work while impaired just because they want to.   THAT is a classic strawman argument... you know, the kind "many extremists" "exhibit a fondness for."

Don't you feel silly right now?  You should.

Comment: Please show where the Second Militia Act of 1792 supports your claim ? :-

Second Militia Act of 1792 extracts.
The second Act, passed May 8, 1792, provided for the organization of the state militias(between the ages of 18 and 54 in 1862.) Militia members, "...shall within six months thereafter, provide himself..." with a musket, bayonet and belt, two spare flints, a cartridge box with 24 bullets, and a knapsack. Men owning rifles were required to provide a powder horn, ¼ pound of gunpowder, 20 rifle balls, a shooting pouch, and a knapsack. Some occupations were exempt, such as congressmen, stagecoach drivers, and ferryboatmen.
Internet meme cites Dick Act as argument against gun control laws and regs The meme claims the Dick Act "cannot be repealed." In fact parts of the Dick Act were effectively repealed when it was modified by the Militia Act of 1908, the National Defense Act of 1916, the National Defense Act of 1920, and the National Defence Act Amendments of 1933

Missed the big one when Snowbank-Snookie handed out three grand.  But I'm registered to vote, and usually do so.  I won't vote for president this year thanks to the odious available "choices", but there are local issues in which I'll want to have my say:

“If you are part of a society that votes, then do so. There may be no candidates and no measures you want to vote for ... but there are certain to be ones you want to vote against. In case of doubt, vote against.  By this rule you will rarely go wrong. If this is too blind for your taste, consult some well-meaning fool (there is always one around) and ask his advice. Then vote the other way. This enables you to be a good citizen (if such is your wish) without spending the enormous amount of time on it that truly intelligent exercise of franchise requires.”--R. A. Heinlein

Comment: Trump sullies the reputation of people who have signed on with him. The respected general H.R. McMaster, now the national security adviser, humiliated himself by trying—presumably under orders—to combat the Washington Post story on May 15 that Trump had revealed highly classified intelligence about ISIS to Lavrov and Kislyak. 

Trump’s reckless act is believed to have endangered the life of an Israeli intelligence asset who had been planted among ISIS forces, something extremely hard to pull off. Trump’s mishandling of the intelligence provoked dismay in Washington.

People can have a hard time recognizing that they’ve been conned. And Trump is skilled at flimflam, creating illusions. But how long can he keep blaming his failures to deliver on others—Democrats, the “dishonest media,” the Washington “swamp”? None of this is knowable yet. What is knowable is that an increasingly agitated Donald Trump’s hold on the presidency is beginning to slip.

Elizabeth Drew, May 25, 2017

Comment: Visa and MasterCard have tripled their charges in last decade; which go unreported and unquestioned. Why don't they fix security flaw in their card scheme...? This is all in the name of convenience.  If cards are made to mandatorily work on 2FA, then risk loading can come down significantly. 2% on credit card can reduce to 0.9%.

Why should a merchant pay, when the credit is being taken by the consumer. Argument has gone stale that credit induces more sales. Today, credit card is only a mechanism to defer the payments.

Comment: Surrendering sovereignty of the state is exactly what the federal system achieves in the US, is it not? The EU is not that integrated a system and yet Americans seem to be largely content with what is rejected here -- creating a federalised superstate. Seriously, isn't the US system the willing subjection of local control to larger, national controls?

The EU is contested on this locus of control, precisely because of  fundamental safeguards for each country's self-governing while working with other countries. It's our way to achieve much of what Americans find necessary, but without such strong national controls. 

How can what is good for you then be bad for us? Many of us felt it was a much wiser path to reform things than to pitch it all in a huff. Government takes reasonable heads, not hot ones.

This demonstrates a severe lack of understanding about the laws in the United States. For example, in North Carolina, you may not withdraw consent for sex. In State v. Way (1979) the state decided that once consent is given, and sexual intercourse has begun, continuing to have sex after the other partner withdraws consent cannot be charged as rape. That means if it starts out nice and fun, and one partner gets violent, too freaking bad. Additionally, several states require that physical force be used for marital intercourse to be charges as rape. Therefore other types of force, coercion, incapacitation through drugs, or having sex with your spouse while they are asleep and thus unable to consent, do not count as rape. Ridiculous laws like this are both proposed, and passed, in this country, and you really should read up on the law if you are going to make claims like this.

Comment: Given Oregon's long history of racism I applaud anyone who works to overcome the lingering effects of that scourge upon our society, and Mark Harris has certainly had an innovative approach.

Being an ardent  supporter of both Frederick Douglass and Abraham Lincoln as well as a staunch critic of both Donald Trump and Ben Carson, I found his proposition quite, well, uh, "interesting."  

While I don't agree with his Lincoln-Trump comparison, Mr. Harris is correct that there are reasons for, as well as against, a campus BRT.  The key is that it be handled by competent, objective professionals who are sensitive to both  issues of  academic free speech and racism.

You will note that  "having a meal with all your friends" does not appear.  It is argued that the meal aspect of the mass was emphasized (and the sacrificial aspect downplayed) so that our protestant brethren would feel more comfortable at mass. How'd that go?  Also see Trent Session 22 for elaboration on mass as a sacrifice.

Comment: What I really don't understand about the rational behind making gun control one of the major platforms for half of the country is that it is not the best use of the limited resource that is our national attention span.  

I don't disagree that the country needs to find a way to curb violent homicides, assaults and accidental death, but taking away guns isn't where we can do the most good - not even slightly.

Guns were involved in 1.3% of all deaths in 2013 - that included 11,208 by homicide, 21,175 by suicide and 505 in cases like this, accidental shootings.  

100% of the deaths by suicide could potentially have been prevented by better mental health care and probably 75-80% of the homicides could have been prevented if the perpetrators had better economic opportunities.

Meanwhile heart disease took 611,105 people, cancer 584,881, respiratory diseases 149,205, mechanical accidents and drowning  130,052, and strokes killed 128,978. Being unhealthy, stupid and smoking are the issues.
